So, why this familiar essay?

Well, the familiar essay is a subset of the personal essay, but not quite as personal as the personal essay that we know in 21st century, the personal essay in which the writer essentially regurgitates his interims unto the page and doesn't talk about anything but himself.

In the early 19th century, essayists like Charles Lamb and William Hazlett wrote what they called familiar essays that were about them but also about a subject that is - Lamb, for example, wrote about tailors and drunkards and annoying relatives, familiar subjects that he knew well and that his readers knew well too.

For example, when I was writing about coffee, I got to drink an enormous amount of coffee, but I also got to read an enormous amount about coffee.
I'd always been curious about the influence of the English coffee house on 17th century literature.
